headline: Saudi's Public Investment Fund dissolves stake in Take-Two Interactive
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund has ‌dissolved its stake in ‌Take-Two Interactive, a regulatory filing showed on ​Tuesday, ahead of the videogame publisher's highly anticipated launch of "Grand Theft Auto VI."  The PIF, ‌Saudi Arabia's ⁠sovereign wealth fund, was Take-Two's second-largest shareholder with ⁠around 11 million shares worth just under $3 billion, according ​to data ​from LSEG.

content.title: Saudi's Public Investment Fund dissolves stake in Take-Two Interactive
content.summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund has ‌dissolved its stake in ‌Take-Two Interactive, a regulatory filing showed on ​Tuesday, ahead of the videogame publisher's highly anticipated launch of "Grand Theft Auto VI."  The PIF, ‌Saudi Arabia's ⁠sovereign wealth fund, was Take-Two's second-largest shareholder with ⁠around 11 million shares worth just under $3 billion, according ​to data ​from LSEG.

headline: Saudi's Public Investment Fund transfers stake in Take-Two Interactive
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund has transferred its ‌stake in Take-Two ⁠Interactive to a subsidiary, a regulatory filing showed ⁠on Tuesday, ahead of the videogame publisher's highly anticipated launch ​of "Grand Theft ​Auto VI."  The ​PIF, Saudi Arabia's ‌sovereign wealth fund, was Take-Two's second-largest shareholder with around 11 million shares worth just under $3 billion, according to data from ‌LSEG.  Last year, the ‌PIF and others agreed ​to acquire ​Take-Two rival Electronic Arts in a $55 billion deal as ​part of ‌its gaming bet.

content.title: Saudi's Public Investment Fund transfers stake in Take-Two Interactive
content.summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund has transferred its ‌stake in Take-Two ⁠Interactive to a subsidiary, a regulatory filing showed ⁠on Tuesday, ahead of the videogame publisher's highly anticipated launch ​of "Grand Theft ​Auto VI."  The ​PIF, Saudi Arabia's ‌sovereign wealth fund, was Take-Two's second-largest shareholder with around 11 million shares worth just under $3 billion, according to data from ‌LSEG.  Last year, the ‌PIF and others agreed ​to acquire ​Take-Two rival Electronic Arts in a $55 billion deal as ​part of ‌its gaming bet.
